column93: Systematic reviews cannot replace animal experiments in the Swiss legal system because such experiments would not be allowed to be conducted. The knowledge would be already available. Hence systematic reviews may only fill the gap wherever knowledge is already available but inaccessible/not-yet-accepted. It is, hence, not an alternative method but constitutes an elementary part of the scientific endeavour.
column94: The judgement of scientific evidence in biomedicine requires field-specific knowledge, with usually multiple orthogonal methods being applied. The methods used will always vary from study to study. It will be difficult to assess this in a standardized fashion (or at least it will be limiting).

column93: If animal experimentations were planned seriously and a thorough review has been done befor of the current literature, the question does not really apply. If you want to prove a new mechanism of whatever pathogenesis or fnctions of new materials, no review could replace this original work. If you plan to promote a new product for medical use, there are regulatory rules to follow. They require experiments for proof of principle and will never allow to be replaced by review.

column93:
I think that a systematic review can never really be used as an alternative for animal experimentation. 

I think that a systematic review could however massively help to stop/reduce unnecessary animal testing, for example you might find the experiment you want to do has been done before etc...

But if you have an entirely or mostly novel experiment in mind then I think you probably have to do the test as animal experiments are still necessary to generate new data that no-one has yet.

The easier it becomes to do systematic reviews the more people will use them too, but first the papers have to include clear data and be written in a way that enables the systematic reviews to be performed well, e.g. with a clear methods section, no missing data etc... Perhaps tools like chatGPT and other large language models will help simplify the process in the future...
column94: It would be great if there were some online tool where you could search a topic and get a really nice summary/review without having to find and go through all the papers yourself, or maybe even a service that would help an inexperienced user with limited time do this.
